description: The Land of Kings - Rajasthan is known for its royal heritage, magnificent forts, palaces, vibrant culture, and desert landscapes.

places.name: Amber Fort
places.description: Majestic hilltop fort with stunning architecture
places.details: Amber Fort is a UNESCO World Heritage Site known for its artistic Hindu style elements. Built in 1592 by Raja Man Singh I, the fort features the magnificent Sheesh Mahal (Mirror Palace) with intricate mirror work, Diwan-e-Aam (Hall of Public Audience), and offers elephant rides to the entrance. The fort showcases a perfect blend of Hindu and Mughal architecture.

secondary.label: Virtual Tour
secondary.content: Experience a 360Â° virtual tour of Amber Fort's magnificent halls, courtyards, and the famous Sheesh Mahal with its thousands of mirrors.

places.name: Hawa Mahal
places.description: The Palace of Winds with intricate lattice work
places.details: Built in 1799 by Maharaja Sawai Pratap Singh, this five-story palace has 953 small windows (jharokhas) designed to allow royal ladies to observe street festivals without being seen. The palace is made of red and pink sandstone and features a unique honeycomb structure.

secondary.label: Learn More
secondary.content: Discover the fascinating history and architecture of this iconic pink sandstone palace, including its unique ventilation system and royal traditions.

places.name: City Palace
places.description: Royal residence with museums and courtyards
places.details: The City Palace complex includes the Chandra Mahal and Mubarak Mahal, housing royal artifacts, textiles, and weapons. Built by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II, it showcases a blend of Rajasthani and Mughal architecture with beautiful courtyards and gardens.

secondary.label: Audio Guide
secondary.content: Get an audio guide to explore the palace's rich history, royal collections, and architectural marvels with detailed commentary.

places.name: Jantar Mantar
places.details: Built by Maharaja Jai Singh II in 1734, this observatory contains 19 astronomical instruments including the world's largest stone sundial (Samrat Yantra). It's a UNESCO World Heritage Site showcasing ancient Indian astronomy and mathematics.

secondary.label: Guided Tour
secondary.content: Join a guided tour to understand the astronomical significance of these ancient instruments and their role in Indian science.

places.name: Dal Baati Churma
places.description: Traditional Rajasthani thali with lentils and wheat balls
places.details: Dal Baati Churma is Rajasthan's signature dish - a complete meal featuring spicy dal (lentils), baked baati (wheat balls), and sweet churma (crumbled baati with sugar). This hearty meal was traditionally prepared by Rajput warriors and is served with ghee and pickles.

primary.label: Find Restaurants
primary.query: traditional Rajasthani thali restaurants near City Palace Jaipur

secondary.label: Recipe Guide
secondary.content: Learn to make authentic Dal Baati Churma at home with traditional cooking methods and authentic Rajasthani spices.

places.name: Laal Maas
places.description: Spicy red mutton curry with Mathania chilies
places.details: Laal Maas is a fiery red mutton curry made with Mathania chilies, yogurt, and traditional spices. This royal dish was originally prepared for Rajput kings and is known for its intense heat and rich flavor. It's typically served with bajra roti or rice.

primary.label: Find Restaurants
primary.query: authentic Laal Maas restaurants Jaipur traditional cuisine

secondary.label: View Menu
secondary.content: Explore the complete menu featuring Laal Maas and other traditional Rajasthani meat dishes with authentic preparation methods.

places.name: Ghewar
places.details: Ghewar is a disc-shaped sweet made from flour, ghee, and sugar syrup, traditionally prepared during Teej festival. This crispy dessert is soaked in sugar syrup and topped with rabri (thickened milk) and dry fruits. It's a symbol of celebration and joy in Rajasthan.

primary.label: Find Restaurants
primary.query: traditional Rajasthani sweets Ghewar shops Jaipur

places.name: Ghoomar Dance
places.description: Traditional Rajasthani folk dance by women
places.details: Ghoomar is a traditional folk dance performed by women in colorful ghagra-choli, characterized by graceful twirling movements. This dance is performed during festivals and celebrations, especially during Gangaur festival. The dancers move in circles while singing traditional songs.

places.name: Kalbelia Dance
places.details: Kalbelia dance is performed by the Kalbelia community, traditionally snake charmers. This UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage dance mimics snake movements with fluid, serpentine motions. Dancers wear black costumes with silver embroidery and perform to traditional instruments.

secondary.label: Cultural Center
secondary.content: Visit cultural centers to witness authentic Kalbelia performances and learn about this UNESCO-recognized art form.

places.name: Block Printing
places.details: Rajasthan is famous for its block printing, especially in Bagru and Sanganer villages. Artisans use wooden blocks carved with intricate designs to print patterns on fabric using natural dyes. This 500-year-old technique creates beautiful textiles with unique patterns.

secondary.label: Shop Handicrafts
secondary.content: Browse and purchase authentic block-printed textiles, including sarees, dupattas, and home decor items from traditional artisans.

places.name: Diwali Festival
places.description: Festival of Lights celebrated across Rajasthan
places.details: Diwali in Rajasthan is celebrated with great enthusiasm, featuring oil lamps, fireworks, traditional sweets, and family gatherings. The Pink City of Jaipur is beautifully illuminated, and markets are decorated with lights. Traditional rituals include Lakshmi Puja and exchanging gifts.

primary.label: Learn More
primary.content: Discover the rich traditions of Diwali in Rajasthan, including special rituals, traditional foods, and cultural significance.

places.name: Pushkar Camel Fair
places.description: World's largest camel fair and cultural festival
places.details: Held annually in November, this vibrant fair features camel trading, cultural performances, religious ceremonies, and competitions. Thousands of camels, horses, and cattle are traded, while cultural shows, folk dances, and traditional music entertain visitors from around the world.

primary.label: Learn More
primary.content: Explore the fascinating world of Pushkar Camel Fair, including trading traditions, cultural performances, and festival highlights.

places.name: Jaipur Literature Festival
places.details: Held annually in January, this festival brings together authors, poets, and literary enthusiasts from around the world. The festival features book launches, panel discussions, poetry readings, and cultural performances, making it a celebration of literature and ideas.

primary.label: Learn More
primary.content: Explore the world's largest free literary festival featuring renowned authors, cultural performances, and intellectual discussions.

places.name: Rajput Dynasties
places.description: Warrior clans who ruled Rajasthan for centuries
places.details: The Rajputs were warrior clans who ruled various parts of Rajasthan from the 6th century onwards. Known for their valor, chivalry, and architectural achievements, they built magnificent forts and palaces. Major dynasties included Sisodias of Mewar, Kachwahas of Jaipur, and Rathores of Jodhpur.

primary.label: Learn More
primary.content: Dive deep into the fascinating history of Rajput dynasties, their battles, architectural marvels, and cultural contributions.

places.name: Maharana Pratap
places.description: Legendary Rajput warrior and freedom fighter
places.details: Maharana Pratap (1540-1597) was a legendary Rajput king of Mewar who fought against Mughal emperor Akbar. Known for his courage and refusal to submit to foreign rule, he is celebrated as a symbol of resistance and valor. His horse Chetak is also legendary for its loyalty.

primary.label: Learn More
primary.content: Discover the heroic tales of Maharana Pratap, his battles, his legendary horse Chetak, and his enduring legacy in Indian history.

monuments.name: Monuments & Tourist Spots
monuments.description: Rajasthan is home to some of India's most magnificent architectural marvels. From the UNESCO World Heritage Sites like Amber Fort and Jantar Mantar to the iconic Hawa Mahal and City Palace, these monuments showcase the grandeur of Rajput architecture. Each fort and palace tells stories of royal valor, strategic warfare, and artistic brilliance that have stood the test of time.

food.name: Food & Cuisine
food.description: Rajasthani cuisine reflects the royal heritage and desert lifestyle of the region. Known for its bold flavors, rich spices, and unique cooking methods, the cuisine includes signature dishes like Dal Baati Churma, Laal Maas, and Ghewar. The food culture emphasizes preservation techniques developed for the harsh desert climate, resulting in dishes that are both nutritious and delicious.

customs.name: Customs & Traditions
customs.description: Rajasthan's customs and traditions are deeply rooted in its royal past and desert culture. From the graceful Ghoomar dance performed by women to the UNESCO-recognized Kalbelia dance of snake charmers, the state's folk traditions are vibrant and diverse. Traditional crafts like block printing, blue pottery, and miniature paintings continue to thrive, preserving centuries-old techniques.

festivals.name: Festivals & Culture
festivals.description: Rajasthan comes alive with colorful celebrations throughout the year. From the world-famous Pushkar Camel Fair to the Jaipur Literature Festival, the state hosts events that attract visitors globally. Traditional festivals like Diwali, Teej, and Gangaur showcase the rich cultural heritage, while modern events blend tradition with contemporary arts and literature.

history.name: History & Trivia
history.description: Rajasthan's history is a tapestry of valor, romance, and architectural brilliance. The Rajput dynasties ruled for centuries, building magnificent forts and palaces while maintaining their independence. Legendary figures like Maharana Pratap symbolize courage and resistance, while the strategic alliances and battles shaped the course of Indian history. The state's heritage continues to inspire and fascinate visitors.
